First, I agree with everything that Mike Clark and J.B. said. :-) But, I do=
 want to add my 1/50th of a Federal Reserve Note concerning using JUnit on =
a large project.

I am the technical lead for a large project here at Lands=
' End. (How do I define a large project? If it goes wrong, then two VP's ge=
t very upset and tens of thousands of customers are affected ... that's lar=
ge in my book.) We use JUnit for unit tests and to drive both functional an=
d load tests (a little pragmatic automation in action! :-)

Here are my tho=
ughts on the pros and cons of using unit tests:

cons:

1. You actually hav=
e to write unit test code.
2. You have to maintain unit test code.

pros:

=
Too many to list here. Just spend about two minutes googling or surfing jun=
it.org and you'll get a bunch.

I think that if I could say only one thing =
about unit testing that people would remember, it would be this: "Unit test=
ing is the first toll booth on the road to software quality." (You may refe=
r to this as Chappell's third law of Software Development). While I'd be th=
e first to say that there is more to software quality than unit testing, un=
it testing is the gateway to software quality. If you don't unit test, then=
 it's either unlikely that you are doing the other requirements for softwar=
e quality or you are trying to do them and they're failing because your bas=
ic building blocks (your testable units of software) are poorly written.

I=
 could write more, but that was the main point I wanted to make that wasn't=
 already covered by the other excellent responses.

Simon
